newsitem.title: JAPAN: Tokyo gold futures mostly weaker amid IMF concerns.
newsitem.headline: Tokyo gold futures mostly weaker amid IMF concerns.

text.p: Yen-denominated gold futures ended mostly lower on Thursday, as spot gold prices were under selling pressure ahead of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) meeting on Friday to discuss a gold sales plan, traders said.
Most active benchmark August ended two yen lower at 1,337 yen, down from the day's high of 1,345 yen.
Other contracts ranged from five yen per gram weaker to three yen firmer.
Bullion slipped to $381.90/382.40 per ounce at 0734 GMT, on selling by overseas investors, against $383.00/383.50 in New York on Wednesday.

"The spot gold market was nervous due to IMF talks on possible gold sales, and spot gold may probe support at $380 per ounce," a trading house trader said. Producers' selling was detected in the spot gold market during Asian hours.
In the gold futures market, early bargain-hunting buying in response to the yen's drop ebbed in the afternoon session, pressured by the bearish spot gold market.
"Gold futures are more sensitive to bearish factors recently, rather than to bullish factors," an analyst at a commodity broker said.
Platinum and palladium futures also settled weaker.
Sentiment in platinum group metals remains bearish, with no bullish factors in sight. Amid a lack of buying interest by private investors, selling by trade houses weighed down prices.
Platinum futures ranged from four to eight yen per gram lower with benchmark August finishing down four at 1,368 yen.
Palladium futures ranged from five yen per gram weaker to four yen higher. Benchmark August was down three at 433 yen.
Silver futures were mixed, ranging from 1.1 yen per 10 grams lower to 0.6 yen firmer. Benchmark August was down 1.1 yen at 181.1 yen.
